questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the physician for a scheduled colonoscopy. She was diagnosed with familial adenomatous polyposis at the age of 13 years. Last year, flexible sigmoidoscopy showed 12 adenomatous polyps (< 6 mm) that were removed endoscopically. Her father and her paternal grandmother were diagnosed with colon cancer at the age of 37 and 39 years, respectively. The patient appears nervous but otherwise well. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. A colonoscopy shows hundreds of diffuse 4–9 mm adenomatous polyps covering the colon and > 30 rectal adenomas. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with a diagnosis of FAP or who are at risk for developing FAP based on family history are generally screened with yearly colonoscopies. Because this patient has experienced a dramatic increase in the number of colonic polyps in the past year, conducting another colonoscopy in 6 months would be inappropriate given her risk of developing colorectal cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

Although an endoscopic biopsy would help differentiate between grades of dysplasia, the sheer number of polyps in this patient puts her at high risk of cancer development.

C) INCORRECT:

Sulindac may cause polyp regression in patients with FAP but does not decrease the risk of cancer. It is generally used as an adjunct for patients whose disease development is being monitored via colonoscopies. Given the patient's dramatic increase in the number of colonic polyps in the past year, medical therapy alone is no longer sufficient.

D) CORRECT:

A marked increase in polyps from the previous colonoscopy in a patient with FAP is an indication for proctocolectomy with ileoanal anastomosis. Other indications for proctocolectomy with ileoanal anastomosis are colorectal cancer, high-grade dysplasia, and inability to survey the colon because of polyps. This patient requires continuous follow-up after surgery because cancer can occur in the ileum or the remaining rectum.

E) INCORRECT:

This chemotherapeutic regimen is one that is used as adjuvant therapy for colon cancer. The patient does not have biopsy-proven colon cancer and will have to await pathology results before considering further medical therapy.

F) INCORRECT:

Imaging would be an option if extraintestinal disease were suspected (e.g., Gardner syndrome). The patient has vital signs within normal limits, no significant findings on exam, and laboratory values including CBC that are within reference ranges; her disease is most likely localized to the colon and rectum.
questions.hint: The patient's diagnosis of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) significantly increases her risk of early colorectal cancer.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of progressive fatigue. He also has shortness of breath and palpitations, which worsen on physical exertion and improve with rest. He has had intermittent constipation, low-grade fever, and generalized myalgias for the past three months. He has had a 10.4-kg (23-lb) weight loss over the past four months despite no change in appetite. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg. Examination shows pale conjunctivae. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.1 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 70 μm3, and serum ferritin is 12 ng/mL. Testing of the stool for occult blood is positive. Colonoscopy shows a 1.7-cm wide exophytic ulcer with irregular, bleeding edges in the ascending colon. Which of the following biopsy findings is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A leiomyomatous polyp is most often a benign lesion of the muscularis propria or muscularis mucosa (smooth muscle of the gastrointestinal tract) with a very low potential for malignancy. Although they can present with pain, constipation, weight loss, and blood in stool, bleeding, as seen in this patient, it is unlikely to have been a predisposing factor as this type of polyp chiefly affects young women and girls.

B) INCORRECT:

Regardless of size, a submucosal lipomatous polyp carries a very low risk of malignant transformation. Lipomas are most commonly found subcutaneously. However, when found in the colon, they can become large, fungating, and ulcerated, which can mimic the appearance of primary colorectal cancer. This patient's anemia could be the result of an ulcerated polyp of this kind, but it would not explain his constitutional symptoms.

C) CORRECT:

The strongest predisposing factor for malignant transformation is the histological subtype of the lesion, followed by its size, location, and gross appearance. Adenomatous polyps (tubular adenoma, tubulovillous adenoma, villous adenoma) carry the highest risk of malignant transformation of all types of colonic polyps. A villous adenomatous polyp has the highest risk (∼ 50%) of malignant transformation of the three types of adenomatous polyps. The larger the villous polyp, the higher the risk.
Image Description:

Types of colonic polyps are depicted from left to right in descending order of their incidence.

D) INCORRECT:

Regardless of size, a pedunculated inflammatory polyp does not carry any risk of neoplastic transformation itself. However, the tissue surrounding these polyps is prone to dysplasia (and therefore a higher risk of neoplastic transformation) due to the constant inflammation in the area. Regardless, this type of polyp is only seen in advanced inflammatory bowel disease, which this patient has no history of.

E) INCORRECT:

Serrated polyps carry a moderate risk of malignant transformation. Of the three main types of serrated polyps (hyperplastic, sessile serrated, and traditional serrated) hyperplastic polyps carry the lowest risk of malignancy.

F) INCORRECT:

A tubular adenoma is the most common histological variety of colonic adenoma, comprising ∼ 80% of all adenomatous polyps. These common polyps carry a relatively small risk of malignant transformation (∼ 5%). Increasing size is associated with a higher risk of malignancy. However, another type of polyp is a greater predisposing factor for this patient's condition.

G) INCORRECT:

Regardless of size, sessile hamartomatous polyps are generally a benign finding and unlikely to result in malignant transformation. Although hamartomatous polyps found in the context of certain conditions (e.g., Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, Juvenile polyposis syndrome, Cowden syndrome) have an increased risk of malignant transformation, this patient lacks other signs or symptoms characteristic of these syndromes.
questions.hint: This patient presents with constitutional symptoms and iron deficiency anemia, in the setting of an ulcerative, bleeding growth in the colon. These findings are highly suggestive of colorectal cancer.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2 day history of blood-speckled stools and a protruding rectal mass. He has no abdominal pain, altered bowel habits, or fever. His mother has inflammatory bowel disease. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple, small, hyperpigmented maculae on the lips, buccal mucosa, palms, and soles. The abdomen is soft with no organomegaly. Rectal examination shows a 4-cm pedunculated polyp with superficial excoriations on the mucosa. A colonoscopy shows 14 polyps. A biopsy shows hamartomatous mucosal polyps. This patient's diagnosis is most likely associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Brain tumors, such as medulloblastoma, are not associated with PJS but with Turcot syndrome, a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis. It is important to rule out this condition in anyone presenting with colonic polyps. However, this patient does not present with headaches, behavioral changes, seizures, sensory deficits, or any other features that would indicate an intracranial process. Additionally, he has hamartomatous rather than neoplastic polyps, which rules out FAP.

B) INCORRECT:

Enterovesicular fistula formation is not associated with PJS but is a common complication of Crohn disease (CD), which is an uncommon cause of bloody stools. In addition, this patient's family history is a risk factor for CD. However, the polyps found on colonoscopy and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation are not consistent with CD.

C) INCORRECT:

Mandibular osteomas are not associated with PJS but with Gardner syndrome, a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). The underlying gene mutation predisposes to bony and soft tissue tumors (e.g., osteomas, desmoid tumors, epidermoid cysts) in addition to the colonic findings of FAP. This individual has hamartomatous rather than neoplastic polyps, which rules out FAP.

D) CORRECT:

Individuals with PJS are at increased risk of developing ovarian, breast, and pancreatic cancers. In addition, individuals with PJS have a 40% lifetime risk of developing colorectal cancer.
Image Description:

Dark-brown, hyperpigmented macules are visible on the lips (perioral lentigines).

This is a characteristic cutaneous manifestation of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. Similar spots are typically found on the buccal mucosa, palms, and soles.

E) INCORRECT:

Thyroid adenomas are not associated with PJS but are seen in Cowden syndrome, an autosomal dominant condition that also manifests with GI polyps and skin manifestations. The typical skin manifestations in this syndrome are papules and hyperkeratosis rather than the hyperpigmentation seen here.

F) INCORRECT:

Alopecia is not seen in PJS but in Cronkhite-Canada syndrome (CCS), a rare, nonfamilial disorder that manifests with cutaneous hyperpigmentation (without mucosal involvement) and benign hamartomatous colonic polyps. However, this patient has mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation, which is not associated with CCS.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a protruding rectal polyp and multiple hamartomatous polyps. In combination with mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of bloody stools. During this time, he has not had nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, or pain while defecating. He has had recurrent episodes of nonbloody diarrhea for the past 6 months. His father died of colon cancer at the age of 39 years. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows small, painless bony swellings on the mandible, forehead, and right shin. There are multiple nontender, subcutaneous nodules with central black pores present over the trunk and face. Funduscopic examination shows multiple, oval, darkly pigmented lesions on the retina. Colonoscopy shows approximately 150 colonic polyps. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient has features that are also common in juvenile polyposis syndrome (JPS), including hematochezia, altered bowel habits, numerous polyps on colonoscopy, and a family history of colorectal cancer. However, JPS typically becomes symptomatic before the age of 20 years, and the presence of multiple osteomas, epidermal cysts, and congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium is more suggestive of another condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Family history of colon cancer occurring at a young age is one of the main criteria for hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC). Patients with HNPCC may present with hematochezia and altered bowel habits, as seen here, but colonic polyps are typically absent. Patients with HNPCC are at an increased risk of developing cancers of the stomach, pancreas, small intestine, breast, ovaries, and endometrium. However, the multiple benign tumors that this patient presents with (osteomas, epidermal cysts) and congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium are not seen in HNPCC, making another diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Turcot syndrome is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis. The family history of colon cancer at a young age and the presence of numerous colonic polyps in this patient are typical of FAP. However, this patient has no clinical features of brain tumors (e.g., headaches, focal neurological deficits), which are a defining feature of Turcot syndrome. Although imaging would be necessary to definitively rule out a small asymptomatic brain tumor, the presence of multiple osteomas, epidermal cysts, and congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium in this patient makes another diagnosis more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) can present with hematochezia, altered bowel habits, and a family history of colonic cancer at a young age, as is the case here. However, this patient does not have the common extraintestinal manifestations of PJS (e.g., hyperpigmented spots on the buccal mucosa, lips, palms, and soles). In addition, polyps in PJS are usually few (< 20) and located mainly in the jejunum, unlike the multiple colonic polyps seen here. Lastly, the osteomas, epidermal cysts, and congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium suggest another condition.

E) CORRECT:

Gardner syndrome is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis that manifests with multiple colonic polyps and may cause hematochezia together with extracolonic bone and/or soft tissue lesions, such as osteomas, epidermal cysts, and congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium, all of which are seen here. A family history of colon cancer at a young age furthermore supports this diagnosis. Untreated, Gardner syndrome invariably progresses to colon cancer.
Image Description:

Montage of fundus photographs of a right eye of a 20-year-old woman with a family history of FAP

The presence of ≥ 4 round and oval hyperpigmented retinal lesions (black arrows), some with a depigmented halo, suggest atypical congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE), which is associated with FAP.

In this patient, a follow-up colonoscopy found adenomatous polyps, indicating Gardner syndrome, a subtype of FAP.

F) INCORRECT:

Cowden syndrome can manifest with hematochezia, altered bowel habits, and multiple colonic polyps, as seen in this patient. However, the extraintestinal manifestations of Cowden syndrome include cutaneous papules and hyperkeratosis of the mucocutaneous membranes (often the first symptom), multinodular goiter, and benign breast disorders (e.g., fibroadenoma). The multiple benign tumors (osteomas, epidermal cysts) and congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium seen in this patient make another diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: This condition manifests with dental abnormalities (e.g., supernumerary and/or impacted teeth) in ∼ 30% of patients.

questions.text: A previously healthy 42-year-old man comes to the emergency room with constipation and diffuse, worsening abdominal pain for 2 days. He has no history of major medical illness. His father died in a car accident at the age of 32 years, and his mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus but is otherwise healthy. A diagnosis of bowel obstruction is suspected and he is taken to the operating room for exploratory laparotomy. A partial resection of the colon is performed. The gross appearance of the patient's colonic tissue is shown. Microscopic examination shows tubular, tubulovillous, and villous adenomas. Assuming the patient's partner is not a carrier of the condition, which of the following is the likelihood that this patient’s children will develop this condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If the patient is a homozygous dominant (i.e. two dominant/diseased alleles), there is a 100% probability of passing down a dominant allele to his offspring. Almost all individuals with an autosomal dominant disease have only one affected parent and are thus genetically heterozygous. Even if this man developed a de novo mutation, the probability is exceptionally rare that he developed two de novo mutations in the same gene locus on both alleles, so he would be assumed to be heterozygous as well.

B) INCORRECT:

When both parents are heterozygous for an autosomal recessive disease, the chance of disease inheritance is 25%. FAP is autosomal dominant, not autosomal recessive. Furthermore, there is one affected parent and no carriers in this scenario.

C) INCORRECT:

When both parents are heterozygous for an autosomal dominant disease, the chance of disease inheritance is 75% (50% heterozygous and 25% homozygous dominant). FAP is an autosomal dominant disease, but only one parent is affected in this scenario.

D) CORRECT:

FAP is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in the APC tumor suppressor gene. It can be determined that this patient is heterozygous (i.e., one dominant/disease allele) because his mother is otherwise healthy. In addition, his partner has no FAP (i.e., two recessive/healthy alleles). Therefore, the patient's child has a 50% chance of inheriting one dominant allele and developing FAP.
Image Description:

In autosomal dominant inheritance, only one copy of a disease allele located on autosomes is needed to be passed to cause the expression of the phenotype in an offspring. In this inheritance pattern, there are affected individuals in each generation. Males and females are equally affected. At least one parent of the affected individual carries the disease allele and is affected. Affected males can inherit the phenotype from the affected mother, and affected females can inherit the phenotype from the affected father.

E) INCORRECT:

Some patients have no family history of FAP because they developed a de novo mutation. Regardless of past family history, once the mutation is established in an individual, FAP will be passed down to offspring in an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.

In an exceedingly rare case of mosaicism, certain somatic cells will carry the de novo mutation for FAP while other cells, such as germ cells, will not. This scenario can lead to a 0% probability of disease in the offspring, but mosaicism should not be assumed unless otherwise stated.
questions.hint: This patient has hundreds of colonic polyps with varying histology, consistent with a diagnosis of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue and dyspnea on exertion for 3 months. During this time, he has also had increased straining during defecation and a 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss. He has no personal or family history of serious medical illness. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. Laboratory studies show microcytic anemia. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Colonoscopy shows an exophytic mass in the ascending colon. Pathologic examination of the mass shows a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma. A gain-of-function mutation in which of the following genes is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A loss-of-function mutation (not a gain-of-function mutation) in the tumor suppressor gene Deleted in Colon Cancer (DCC) is a late event in the chromosomal instability pathway (i.e., the adenoma-carcinoma sequence) and promotes malignant transformation of an adenoma to a carcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

A loss-of-function mutation (not a gain-of-function mutation) in the tumor suppressor gene TP53 is a late event in the chromosomal instability pathway (i.e., the adenoma-carcinoma sequence) and promotes malignant transformation of an adenoma to a carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

The microsatellite instability pathway is characterized by a loss-of-function mutation (not a gain-of-function mutation) or epigenetic silencing (i.e., promoter hypermethylation) of mismatch repair genes, including MLH1, and can result in the development of colorectal carcinoma. This mechanism underlies Lynch syndrome. However, it is an uncommon cause of sporadic cases of colorectal carcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

A loss-of-function mutation (not a gain-of-function mutation) of the tumor suppressor gene APC is the initiating event in the chromosomal instability pathway (i.e., the adenoma-carcinoma sequence). This loss-of-function mutation results in decreased intercellular adhesion and increased epithelial proliferation in the colon. Loss-of-function mutations in APC also underlie familial adenomatous polyposis, an inherited syndrome that predisposes to colorectal cancer formation.

E) CORRECT:

Most sporadic cases of colorectal carcinoma arise from the chromosomal instability pathway (i.e., the adenoma-carcinoma sequence). In this pathway, a loss-of-function mutation of the tumor suppressor gene APC results in decreased intercellular adhesion and increased epithelial proliferation. Next, a gain-of-function mutation in the KRAS proto-oncogene results in unregulated cellular signaling and cellular proliferation, which predisposes to adenoma formation. Finally, loss-of-function mutations of additional tumor suppressor genes (e.g., TP53, DCC) results in malignant transformation of an adenoma to a carcinoma.

Gain-of-function mutations in KRAS are also associated with lung cancer and pancreatic cancer.
Image Description:

Top: Chromosomal instability pathway (adenoma-carcinoma sequence)
- Loss of the tumor suppressor gene, APC, results in hyperproliferative epithelium due to a loss of cellular adhesion and increased cellular proliferation. A mutation in KRAS results in unregulated cellular signaling and cellular proliferation, leading to the formation of an adenoma. Loss of the tumor suppressor genes TP53 and DCC results in the malignant transformation of an adenoma to carcinoma. The chromosomal instability pathway is responsible for carcinomas in FAP (loss of APC) as well as in most cases of sporadic colorectal carcinoma.

Bottom: Microsatellite instability pathway
- Acquired or inherited mutations in the mismatch repair genes (esp. MLH1 and MSH2) result in abnormal proliferation and the formation of adenoma and carcinoma. The microsatellite instability pathway is responsible for carcinomas in Lynch syndrome (HNPCC) and a few cases of sporadic colorectal carcinoma.
questions.hint: This patient has iron deficiency anemia (progressive fatigue, dyspnea, conjunctival pallor, microcytic anemia, positive stool occult blood) secondary to a well-differentiated, sporadic, right-sided colorectal carcinoma. Most sporadic cases of colorectal carcinoma progress from adenoma to carcinoma due to chromosomal instability.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He has a strong family history of colon cancer. A screening colonoscopy shows a 4 mm polyp in the upper sigmoid colon. Which of the following findings on biopsy is associated with the lowest potential for malignant transformation into colorectal carcinoma?

choices.text: Branching tubules embedded in lamina propria
Finger-like projections with a fibrovascular core
Hyperplastic epithelium at the base of crypts

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tubular adenomas consist of branching tubules embedded in the lamina propria. These common polyps carry a smaller risk of malignant transformation (approx. 5%) compared to other types of adenomatous polyps but still carry a greater risk of malignant transformation when compared to a different type of polyp.
Image Description:

Top: Chromosomal instability pathway (adenoma-carcinoma sequence)
- Loss of the tumor suppressor gene, APC, results in hyperproliferative epithelium due to a loss of cellular adhesion and increased cellular proliferation. A mutation in KRAS results in unregulated cellular signaling and cellular proliferation, leading to the formation of an adenoma. Loss of the tumor suppressor genes TP53 and DCC results in the malignant transformation of an adenoma to carcinoma. The chromosomal instability pathway is responsible for carcinomas in FAP (loss of APC) as well as in most cases of sporadic colorectal carcinoma.

Bottom: Microsatellite instability pathway
- Acquired or inherited mutations in the mismatch repair genes (esp. MLH1 and MSH2) result in abnormal proliferation and the formation of adenoma and carcinoma. The microsatellite instability pathway is responsible for carcinomas in Lynch syndrome (HNPCC) and a few cases of sporadic colorectal carcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) is associated with multiple non-neoplastic hamartomatous polyps, which typically show tree-like branching of the muscularis mucosa. PJS is associated with an increased risk of colorectal, gastric, breast, and ovarian cancers. The lifetime risk of colorectal cancer is approx. 40%.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a colonic polyp (H&E stain; 200× magnification)

Hyperplastic smooth muscle cells (uninucleated spindle-shaped cells) are visible as broad pink bands arranged in a tree-like pattern. Glandular hyperplasia without distortion of the normal tissue architecture is also visible.

These features are consistent with a hamartomatous polyp, which is typically seen in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Regenerating epithelium with inflammatory infiltrate is found in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., ulcerative colitis) and can manifest as pseudopolyps. While pseudopolyps only carry a low risk of malignant transformation, patients with chronic inflammatory bowel disease generally have an increased risk of colorectal cancer because of persistent cell damage from recurrent inflammation.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of colonic polyp tissue (H&E stain; low magnification)

Multiple dilated and slightly tortuous crypts (crypt hyperplasia) are visible (example indicated by red dashed outline). In the top left corner, epithelium with numerous mitotic figures can be seen, corresponding to epithelial regeneration (examples indicated by yellow overlay). There is an inflammatory infiltrate in the lamina propria (seen as numerous dark blue dots; example marked by black arrowhead). Two crypt abscesses can be seen in the center and on the right (green overlays). Crypt abscesses contain neutrophils (blue dots) and epithelial debris (pink substance) within their lumen. There is no evidence of dysplasia.

Epithelial regeneration, mucosal inflammation, crypt hyperplasia, and crypt abscesses are characteristic features of an inflammatory pseudopolyp that occurs due to the recurrent mucosal ulceration and healing that typically occurs in ulcerative colitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Villous adenomas consist of finger-like projections with a fibrovascular core. They have the highest risk (approx. 50%) of malignant transformation of the three types of adenomatous polyps (i.e., tubular adenoma, tubulovillous adenoma, or villous adenoma).
Image Description:

Top: Chromosomal instability pathway (adenoma-carcinoma sequence)
- Loss of the tumor suppressor gene, APC, results in hyperproliferative epithelium due to a loss of cellular adhesion and increased cellular proliferation. A mutation in KRAS results in unregulated cellular signaling and cellular proliferation, leading to the formation of an adenoma. Loss of the tumor suppressor genes TP53 and DCC results in the malignant transformation of an adenoma to carcinoma. The chromosomal instability pathway is responsible for carcinomas in FAP (loss of APC) as well as in most cases of sporadic colorectal carcinoma.

Bottom: Microsatellite instability pathway
- Acquired or inherited mutations in the mismatch repair genes (esp. MLH1 and MSH2) result in abnormal proliferation and the formation of adenoma and carcinoma. The microsatellite instability pathway is responsible for carcinomas in Lynch syndrome (HNPCC) and a few cases of sporadic colorectal carcinoma.

E) CORRECT:

Hyperplastic polyps consist of hyperplastic epithelium at the base of the crypts of Lieberkuhn. They are a common type of polyp and most frequently occur in the rectosigmoid and left colon. Hyperplastic polyps are benign and carry a very low risk of transforming into malignancy because there is no dysplasia present. Other examples of polyps that are benign include mucosal polyps and submucosal polyps.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of colonic polyp tissue (H&E stain)

The luminal crypt epithelium shows prominent serration (sawtooth pattern). Goblet cell hyperplasia appears as vacuous bubbles in the crypt epithelium due to the mucin content. There is crowding of cells at the base of the crypts of Lieberkuhn (basal hyperplasia).
questions.hint: Small epithelial proliferation in the rectosigmoid colon has the lowest potential for malignant transformation.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 9-month history of progressive fatigue. Examination shows pallor. Her hemoglobin concentration is 8.9 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 75 μm3, and serum ferritin is 6 ng/mL. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Colonoscopy shows an irregular, bleeding 3-cm exophytic ulcer in the right colon. Which of the following lesions is the strongest risk factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A submucosal lipomatous polyp carries a very low risk of malignant transformation. Lipomas are most commonly found subcutaneously. When found in the colon, they can become large, fungating, and ulcerated, which can mimic the appearance of primary colorectal cancer. If ulcerated, they may also rarely lead to (occult) gastrointestinal bleeding. However, lipomas do not cause constitutional symptoms, which this patient has.

B) INCORRECT:

Sessile hamartomatous polyps are generally a benign finding and unlikely to result in malignant transformation, although in the context of certain conditions (i.e., Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, Juvenile polyps, and Cowden syndrome), they have an increased risk of malignant transformation.

C) INCORRECT:

Serrated polyps carry a moderate risk of malignant transformation. Of the three main types of serrated polyps (hyperplastic, sessile serrated, and traditional serrated), hyperplastic polyps carry the lowest risk of malignancy because there is no dysplasia present.

D) CORRECT:

Adenomatous polyps (i.e., tubular adenoma, tubulovillous adenoma, or villous adenoma) carry the highest risk of malignant transformation of all types of colonic polyps. A villous adenomatous polyp has the highest risk (∼ 50%) of malignant transformation of the three types of adenomatous polyps.
Image Description:

Types of colonic polyps are depicted from left to right in descending order of their incidence.

E) INCORRECT:

Tubular adenoma is the most common histological variety of colonic adenoma, comprising ∼ 80% of all adenomatous polyps. These common polyps carry a relatively small risk of malignant transformation (∼ 5%). Increasing size is associated with a higher risk of malignancy. However, another type of polyp is a greater predisposing factor for this patient's condition.

F) INCORRECT:

A leiomyomatous polyp is most often a benign lesion of the muscularis propria or muscularis mucosa (smooth muscle of the gastrointestinal tract) with a very low potential for malignancy. Although they can present with pain, constipation, weight loss, and blood in stool, bleeding, as seen in this patient, it is unlikely to have been a predisposing factor as this type of polyp chiefly affects young women and girls.

G) INCORRECT:

A pedunculated inflammatory polyp, which is seen only in advanced IBD, does not carry any risk of neoplastic transformation. The tissue surrounding a pedunculated inflammatory polyp, as opposed to the inflammatory polyp itself, is prone to dysplasia and therefore at higher risk of neoplastic transformation.
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptomatic iron deficiency anemia and is found to have an irregular, ulcerative growth in the right colon. These findings are highly suggestive of colorectal cancer.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after a colonoscopy showed 42 hamartomatous polyps. The physical examination findings are shown in the photograph. Which of the following conditions is most likely to develop in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is not associated with an increased risk of mandibular osteomas. Mandibular osteomas and soft tissue tumors (e.g., desmoid tumors, sebaceous cysts) are associated with Gardner syndrome, a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), which would present with colonic polyps. However, the polyps in FAP would be adenomatous rather than hamartomatous, and patients with FAP would typically have thousands of polyps.

B) INCORRECT:

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is not associated with an increased risk of pheochromocytoma. The risk of pheochromocytoma is increased in neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL), and multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type 2. NF1 can cause hyperpigmented macules (café au lait spots), intestinal neuromas, and hamartomatous nodules in the iris (Lisch nodules), but the café au lait spots would be seen on the trunk in association with cutaneous neurofibromas, and hamartomatous intestinal polyps would not be expected. MEN type 2A can cause intestinal neuromas and VHL can cause intestinal cavernous hemangiomas, but neither MEN type 2A nor VHL would be associated with hamartomatous polyps or perioral hyperpigmented macules.

C) INCORRECT:

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is not associated with an increased risk of medulloblastoma. Brain tumors such as medulloblastoma and gliomas are associated with Turcot syndrome, a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), which would manifest with colonic polyps. However, the polyps in FAP would be adenomatous rather than hamartomatous and patients with FAP would typically have thousands of polyps.

D) INCORRECT:

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is not associated with an increased risk of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Seborrheic keratosis can appear as a pigmented macule, and multiple seborrheic keratoses (Leser-Trelat sign) can be a harbinger of lymphoid malignancies (e.g., non-Hodgkin lymphoma) or gastrointestinal malignancies. However, seborrheic keratoses typically appear on the head, trunk, and extremities, in contrast to the perioral pigmented macules seen in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) is a rare autosomal dominant condition caused by a hyperactive serine-threonine kinase due to a gain of function mutation on the STK11 gene on chromosome 19. Patients with PJS develop melanotic macules on the lips, buccal mucosa, genitalia, palms, and soles as well as gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps characterized by normal colonic epithelium and branching muscularis mucosae. Possible complications of the hamartomatous polyps include bleeding and intussusception. Individuals with PJS are also at increased risk of malignancies such as colorectal, pancreatic, ovarian, and breast cancer.

F) INCORRECT:

The melanotic macules associated with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome have not been known to develop into a melanoma or any other cutaneous malignancy. Lynch syndrome is associated with sebaceous cutaneous neoplasms and colorectal cancer, but Lynch syndrome does not manifest with intestinal polyposis.

G) INCORRECT:

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is associated with an increased risk of gallbladder carcinoma but not hepatocellular carcinoma. The risk of hepatocellular carcinoma is increased in conditions such as Wilson disease and hemochromatosis, both of which can cause hyperpigmentation. However, hyperpigmentation in Wilson disease predominantly affects the skin, and patients with hemochromatosis would have diffuse cutaneous hyperpigmentation, in contrast to the pigmented perioral macules seen here. Moreover, neither Wilson disease nor hemochromatosis is associated with intestinal polyposis.
questions.hint: Hamartomatous tumors are disorganized growths of well-differentiated tissue in their native location. In combination with mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation, multiple hamartomatous polyps are consistent with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS).

questions.text: A previously healthy 35-year-old woman comes to the physician for a 3-week history of alternating constipation and diarrhea with blood in her stool. She has not had any fevers or weight loss. Her father died of gastric cancer at 50 years of age. Physical examination shows blue-gray macules on the lips and palms of both hands. Colonoscopy shows multiple polyps throughout the small bowel and colon with one ulcerated polyp at the level of the sigmoid colon. Multiple biopsy specimens are collected. These polyps are most likely to be characterized as which of the following histological subtypes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hyperplastic polyps are small growths that are most commonly found in the rectosigmoid colon. Although most hyperplastic polyps are benign, some may evolve into premalignant serrated polyps; therefore, removal is recommended. Hyperplastic polyps are not associated with mucocutaneous discoloration or a family history of gastrointestinal malignancy, both of which are present in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Adenomas are the most common type of neoplastic mucosal polyp. They include tubular adenomas, tubulovillous adenomas, and villous adenomas (with villous features indicating a higher malignant potential). In patients with multiple colorectal adenomas or those who have developed multiple adenomas at an early age, familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome should be suspected. This patient's clinical exam findings are more concerning for PJS, which is characterized by colonic polyps of a different histologic type.
Image Description:

Types of colonic polyps are depicted from left to right in descending order of their incidence.

C) INCORRECT:

Mucosal polyps are small, usually < 5 mm in size, and benign. They are not associated with PJS.

D) INCORRECT:

Serrated polyps, which can be classified as either traditional serrated adenomas or sessile serrated polyps, have moderate potential to undergo malignant transformation. Although serrated polyps are associated with oncogenic mutations, such as BRAF, there is no known connection to PJS.

E) CORRECT:

Hamartomatous polyps are the most likely type to be found in this patient with PJS, a condition that is characterized by numerous hamartomatous colonic polyps, mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation, and an increased risk of gastrointestinal malignancy. In PJS, polyps commonly occur in the small intestine but can be found in any part of the GI tract. Although hamartomas are often benign, a small risk of malignant transformation is present. On histopathology, hamartomas contain a proliferation of smooth muscle extending into the lamina propria with normal overlying epithelium.
questions.hint: The combination of multiple gastrointestinal polyps, mucocutaneous discoloration, and a family history of gastrointestinal malignancy is consistent with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS).

questions.text:
A 31-year-old, previously healthy man presents to the emergency department reporting one week of progressive jaundice. He denies tobacco or alcohol use. He notes that his mother died of gastric cancer when he was a child, and his sister has been diagnosed with endometrial cancer.
On examination, the patient is afebrile and hemodynamically stable. He has jaundice but no spider telangiectasias, and his abdominal examination is unremarkable. Laboratory testing reveals marked elevations of serum bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase.
CT of the abdomen and pelvis shows biliary and pancreatic-duct dilation down to the level of the ampulla without an identifiable mass. Endoscopic ultrasound shows a 1-cm ampullary polyp without invasive features. The polyp is removed by endoscopic ampullectomy and found to be a benign adenoma. The patient’s liver function tests subsequently return to normal.
In addition to referral for genetic counseling, what is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Measurement of calcium and parathyroid hormone levels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography and pancreatoduodenectomy (the Whipple procedure) are not indicated for additional evaluation or treatment of a benign duodenal ampullary adenoma.

B) INCORRECT:

There is no indication to measure calcium and parathyroid hormone levels in this patient. Primary hyperparathyroidism is a component of the multiple endocrine neoplasia syndromes, but these syndromes do not typically increase the risk of duodenal adenomas.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with a strong family history of cancer and a personal history of duodenal adenoma are likely to have a hereditary polyposis syndrome and should undergo colonoscopy to check for colonic polyps. This patient most likely carries a germline mutation in the tumor suppressor gene adenomatous polyposis coli (APC), which is found in familial adenomatous polyposis (including Gardner syndrome) and Turcot syndrome. Another possibility is a mutation in DNA mismatch-repair genes, resulting in Lynch syndrome or Muir-Torre syndrome.

Key learning point: Patients with a history suggestive of a hereditary polyposis syndrome should undergo both genetic testing and colonoscopy to check for polyps.

D) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography and pancreatoduodenectomy (the Whipple procedure) are not indicated for additional evaluation or treatment of a benign duodenal ampullary adenoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Measurement of serum gastrin levels would be indicated if Zollinger-Ellison syndrome were suspected, but it is not associated with ampullary polyps and a family history of cancer.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man with no significant medical history is seen for red blood per rectum. His family history is positive for colon cancer in his father (diagnosed at age 35) and brother (diagnosed at age 31).
His rectal examination is notable for black stool and no masses. Laboratory evaluation reveals a microcytic anemia. A colonoscopy shows more than 100 polyps throughout the colon. Multiple biopsies reveal tubular adenomas without evidence of adenocarcinoma.
Which one of the following management strategies is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Remove polyps greater than 1 cm in size

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s family history and colonoscopy findings suggest a diagnosis of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). FAP, the most common inherited polyposis syndrome, is a result of a germline mutation in the APC gene on chromosome 5. It is inherited as an autosomal dominant disease and, without any intervention, leads invariably to colorectal cancer. Colectomy is the optimal treatment for patients with polyposis and FAP.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management for a patient with familial adenomatous polyposis who is found to have more than 100 colonic polyps is total colectomy.

B) INCORRECT:

Although some studies suggest a benefit of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs in preventing colon cancer, aspirin is not recommended in the setting of polyposis.

C) INCORRECT:

Repeating a colonoscopy in 6 months is not advised given the inevitable development of cancer in FAP.

D) INCORRECT:

Administration of fluorouracil is not appropriate because radiation or chemotherapy has no role in managing a patient with FAP who has not yet developed cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Polypectomy to remove polyps greater than 1 cm is not a viable long-term option because FAP is the result of a germline defect and the entire colonic mucosa is at risk for cancer.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man returns for follow-up after his first screening colonoscopy, during which five polyps ranging from 3 to 5 mm in diameter were all completely removed. All the polyps were found to be tubular adenomas with no high-grade dysplasia. He has no family history of colon cancer, genitourinary cancers, gastric or pancreatic cancers, or colon polyps. He smokes cigarettes but plans to quit soon.
When should this patient undergo repeat colonoscopy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Screening guidelines for colorectal cancer (CRC) vary according to the patient’s baseline risk for CRC as well as their findings on any previous colonoscopy. Smoking status does not factor into these recommendations.

If a patient has an average baseline risk for CRC and either normal findings or adenomas on previous colonoscopy (as in this case), the recommended screening intervals are as shown in the table below. Note that recommendations differ if hyperplastic or sessile serrated polyps are found or if a patient has a high baseline risk because of their personal or family history.

In this case, the patient had five small (< 10 mm) tubular adenomas removed. The next colonoscopy should therefore be scheduled for 3 years.

Key learning point: If five tubular adenomatous polyps ranging from 3 to 5 mm in diameter without villous features or high-grade dysplasia are detected on an initial screening colonoscopy, the appropriate interval for a repeat colonoscopy is 3 years.

B) INCORRECT:

The recommendation for a 7-year interval for surveillance colonoscopy applies to patients who had 1–2 tubular adenomas <10 mm. This patient had five small (<10 mm) tubular adenomas removed, which indicates a 3-year interval.

C) INCORRECT:

The recommendation for a 10-year interval for surveillance colonoscopy applies to patients who had normal baseline colonoscopy findings. This patient had five small (<10 mm) tubular adenomas removed, which indicates a 3-year interval.

D) INCORRECT:

The recommendation for a 5-year interval for surveillance colonoscopy applies to patients who had 3–4 tubular adenomas <10 mm. This patient had five small (<10 mm) tubular adenomas removed, which indicates a 3-year interval.

E) INCORRECT:

The recommendation for a 1-year interval for surveillance colonoscopy applies to patients who had >10 adenomas on a single examination. This patient had five small (<10 mm) tubular adenomas removed, which indicates a 3-year interval.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman with hypertension and a history of depression undergoes a screening colonoscopy. A 9-mm polyp is found in the rectum (figure). No other synchronous lesions are identified in the colon.
Pathologic examination of the polyp after endoscopic resection reveals a completely resected tubular adenoma with high-grade dysplasia but no evidence of submucosal invasion or carcinoma.
When should this patient have her next surveillance colonoscopy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The recommendation for a 10-year interval for surveillance colonoscopy applies to patients who had normal baseline colonoscopy findings.

B) INCORRECT:

The recommendation for a 5-year interval for surveillance colonoscopy applies to patients who had 3–4 tubular adenomas <10 mm.

C) INCORRECT:

The recommendation for a 6-month interval for surveillance colonoscopy applies to patients who had a piecemeal resection of an adenoma ≥20 mm.

D) CORRECT:

Adenomatous polyps, the most common type of colonic polyp, are dysplastic and have malignant potential. Although nearly all colon cancers develop from adenomatous polyps, only a very small percentage of adenomatous polyps progress to cancer. Thus, it is important to recognize varying types of polyps and adjust surveillance screening colonoscopies accordingly.

Patients with any advanced adenoma (≥1 cm or with villous histology or high-grade dysplasia) at baseline colonoscopy should undergo a first surveillance colonoscopy in 3 years. The recommended screening intervals for average-risk patients with normal colonoscopy findings or adenomas are as shown in the “Surveillance after colon polypectomy” table.

Other lesions on colonoscopy that would affect the recommended screening interval in average-risk patients include hyperplastic polyps and sessile serrated polyps (SSPs).

Key learning point: The recommended interval for surveillance colonoscopy after complete removal of a newly diagnosed tubular adenoma with high-grade dysplasia is 3 years.

E) INCORRECT:

The recommendation for a 1-year interval for surveillance colonoscopy applies to patients who had >10 adenomas on a single examination.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old man with no notable medical history reports intermittent cramping abdominal pain. A few weeks earlier, he noticed blood in his stool, which has resolved. He has had no diarrhea, constipation, nausea, anorexia, or weight loss.
His blood pressure and other vital signs are normal, as is his abdominal examination. He has scattered dark-brown macules on the lips (figure), gingiva, and fingers.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gardner syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder that is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis. Its skin manifestations include epidermoid cysts and fibromas. The risk for malignant transformation of colonic polyps in Gardner syndrome approaches 100%.

B) INCORRECT:

In dysplastic nevus syndrome, multiple dysplastic nevi may be present anywhere on the skin but do not preferentially involve the oral mucosa or fingers.

C) CORRECT:

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by melanocytic macules of the lips, buccal mucosa, and digits and by multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps. Anemia, rectal bleeding, and abdominal pain due to obstruction and intussusception are common presenting symptoms in about half of affected patients by 20 years of age. The syndrome, caused by heterozygous pathogenic variants in STK11 tumor-suppressor gene, is associated with increased risk for gastrointestinal, pancreatic, breast, ovarian, lung, and uterine cancers.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a young adult with abdominal pain, intermittent bloody stools, and hyperpigmented macules on the oral mucosa and fingers is Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Cowden syndrome, an autosomal dominant disorder due to heterozygous pathogenic variants in the PTEN gene, is a subtype of PTEN hamartoma tumor syndrome. It is associated with increased risk for thyroid, breast, colorectal, kidney, and uterine cancers. Cutaneous findings include flesh-colored facial papules (trichilemmomas) and oral mucosal papillomatosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Addison disease is characterized by a more generalized hyperpigmentation (as opposed to focal hyperpigmentation on the oral mucosa and palms) with nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, weakness, and weight loss. Unlike patients with polyposis, patients with Addison disease would not be expected to experience intermittent bloody stools.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man underwent screening colonoscopy one week ago. Four polyps were found and resected completely without complications. The pathology revealed tubular adenomas, with the largest (0.8 cm) showing villous features but no evidence of high-grade dysplasia. The patient has no family history of polyposis or colon cancer. He has no intestinal symptoms, such as diarrhea or abdominal pain, and he is not anemic.
At what interval should follow-up colonoscopy be performed in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The recommendation for a 1-year interval for surveillance colonoscopy applies to patients who had >10 adenomas on a single examination. For these patients, underlying familial syndromes should be considered as well. This patient had 4 adenomas.

B) INCORRECT:

The recommendation for a 5-year interval for surveillance colonoscopy applies to patients who had 3–4 tubular adenomas <10 mm. This patient had an adenoma with villous features, which indicates a 3-year interval.

C) CORRECT:

The recommended screening intervals for average-risk patients with normal colonoscopy findings or adenomas are shown in the table below.

For patients who have 3 to 10 adenomas, any adenoma >1 cm, any adenoma with villous features (as in this case), or any evidence of high-grade dysplasia, the next colonoscopy should be performed in 3 years, provided that the adenoma(s) have been completely removed.

Key learning point: The recommended surveillance interval for subsequent colonoscopy after resection of a subcentimeter adenoma with villous features but no high-grade dysplasia is 3 years.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients who are at average risk for colorectal cancer and are found to have one or two small (<1 cm) tubular adenomas with low-grade dysplasia should have their next colonoscopy in 7 to 10 years.

E) INCORRECT:

The recommendation for a 6-month interval for surveillance colonoscopy applies to patients who had a piecemeal resection of an adenoma ≥20 mm, to verify complete removal.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old woman reports that she started noticing dark-red blood in her stools about one month ago. It was initially intermittent but is now present with each bowel movement, mixed in with her stool and on the toilet paper. She denies any abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, or weight loss. Her bowel movements are regular, and she has no constipation or diarrhea. She is otherwise healthy and has no history of surgery. Her mother died in a car crash about 3 years ago, but her father and her two siblings are healthy. Her maternal grandfather and great-grandmother both died from colon cancer at a young age, and her maternal aunt is currently undergoing treatment for medulloblastoma.
The patient has a heart rate of 98 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 110/68 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while breathing ambient air. She has mild conjunctival and palatal pallor but an otherwise normal examination. Her abdomen is soft, nontender, and nondistended. Rectal examination does not reveal any fissures, tags, or hemorrhoids.
Colonoscopy reveals 20 to 30 adenomatous polyps scattered throughout her transverse and descending colon and rectum.
Which one of the following conditions is this patient most likely to develop?

choices.text: Glioma of the central nervous system

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ulcerative colitis is associated with an increased risk for colon cancer, but patients with FAP are not at increased risk for ulcerative colitis.

B) INCORRECT:

The risk for endometrial cancer is increased in patients with hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC; Lynch syndrome) but not FAP. HNPCC is also associated with other malignancies of the gastrointestinal tract, including gastric cancer and biliary cancer, and with gliomas of the central nervous system.

C) INCORRECT:

The risk for endometrial cancer is increased in patients with hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC; Lynch syndrome) but not FAP. Like FAP, HNPCC is an autosomal dominant condition that predisposes individuals to colon cancer in the second and third decades of life, but as the name implies, affected patients do not have a multitude of adenomatous polyps. Patients with HNPCC have an approximately 70% lifetime risk for colon cancer and a 15% to 65% risk for endometrial cancer, depending on the specific mutation in the patient’s family. HNPCC is also associated with other malignancies of the gastrointestinal tract, including gastric cancer and biliary cancer, and with gliomas of the central nervous system.

D) INCORRECT:

FAP is associated with malignancies outside the gastrointestinal tract as well, including follicular or papillary thyroid cancer, hepatoblastoma, and medulloblastoma. However, the lifetime risk for these cancers is much lower (<3%) than the lifetime risk for colon cancer.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has gastrointestinal bleeding, a strong family history of colon cancer, and more than 10 adenomatous polyps detected on colonoscopy. The most likely diagnosis is familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), an autosomal dominant disease that is characterized by the presence of hundreds of thousands of colorectal adenomas in one’s lifetime. Polyposis typically develops in the second and third decade of life, but polyps may begin to emerge as early as age 8, with a mean age of 16.

Given the volume and early onset of polyposis in patients with FAP, the lifetime risk for colon cancer is very high — nearly 100% if the patient does not undergo screening and treatment. Although patients with FAP may present with abdominal pain, diarrhea, or gastrointestinal bleeding (as in this case), most remain asymptomatic until they present with colon cancer. The mean age of colon cancer diagnosis in patients with FAP is 45 years.

Patients with FAP may also develop adenomatous polyps in the upper gastrointestinal tract, most commonly the duodenum. The lifetime risk for duodenal cancer in patients with FAP is 4% to 12%.

Patients with suspected FAP should ideally begin colon cancer surveillance once they reach 10 to 12 years of age. Colectomy is eventually necessary in all patients with FAP, although the timing depends on the progression of the disease.

Key learning point: Without screening or treatment, patients with familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome have a very high risk of developing colon cancer.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy with no notable medical history reports intermittent cramping abdominal pain. A few weeks earlier, he noticed blood in his stool, which has resolved. He has had no diarrhea, constipation, nausea, anorexia, or weight loss.
His blood pressure and other vital signs are normal, as is his abdominal examination. He has scattered dark-brown macules on the lips (figure), gingiva, and fingers.

A) INCORRECT:

Addison disease is characterized by a more generalized hyperpigmentation (as opposed to focal hyperpigmentation on the oral mucosa and palms) with nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, weakness, and weight loss. Cowden syndrome, an autosomal dominant disorder due to heterozygous pathogenic variants in the PTEN gene, is a subtype of PTEN hamartoma tumor syndrome. It is associated with increased risk for thyroid, breast, colorectal, kidney, and uterine cancers. questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy who recently joined your practice presents with no current health concerns. His parents describe a significant family history of intestinal polyps on his father’s side. He does not report seeing blood in his stool.
He has a heart rate of 80 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 110/68 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while breathing ambient air. He has anicteric sclerae and freckles around the mouth. His abdomen is soft, nontender, and nondistended. Rectal examination does not reveal any fissures, tags, or hemorrhoids.
Which one of the following conditions is this patient most likely to develop by 18 years of age?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with PJS have a significantly higher lifetime risk for malignancy, including colorectal cancer and Sertoli cell testicular tumors, than the general population. However, the absolute risk of malignancy by age 18 in this population (about 2%) is much lower than the absolute risk of intussusception at that age.

B) CORRECT:

This patient presents with a family history of gastrointestinal polyps and has perioral mucosal pigmentation on examination. He likely has Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS), which is characterized by hamartomatous polyps scattered throughout the gastrointestinal tract. A clinical diagnosis of PJS can be made if a patient has any of the following conditions:

• At least two hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract
• At least one hamartomatous polyp in a patient with a first-degree relative diagnosed with PJS
• Mucocutaneous freckling in a patient with a family history of PJS in a close relative
• Any number of hamartomatous polyps in a patient with mucocutaneous pigmentation

Children with PJS have a 70% chance of developing intussusception by the age of 18 years, with individual risk dependent on the size of the polyp. Most patients with PJS and intussusception have a lead point in the small intestine.

Key learning point: Patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome often present with mucosal freckling and have polyps in the small intestine, which carry a high risk for small-bowel intussusception.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with PJS have a significantly higher lifetime risk for malignancy, including colorectal cancer and Sertoli cell testicular tumors, than the general population. However, the absolute risk of malignancy by age 18 in this population (about 2%) is much lower than the absolute risk of intussusception at that age.

D) INCORRECT:

Longitudinal pigmented lines of the nails, known as melanonychia, are associated with Laugier-Hunziker syndrome, a benign hyperpigmentation disorder that is also associated with hyperpigmented lesions on the lips, such as in PJS; however, this syndrome is not associated with polyps and is typically a diagnosis of exclusion.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) are at high risk for both colonic adenocarcinoma and periampullary duodenal adenocarcinoma; the risk for these types of tumors is not as high in patients with PJS. Medulloblastoma can also occur in FAP but is not commonly associated with PJS.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 9-month history of progressive fatigue. Examination shows pallor. Laboratory studies show iron deficiency anemia. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Colonoscopy shows an irregular, bleeding 3-cm exophytic ulcer in the right colon. Which of the following lesions is the strongest risk factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sessile hamartomatous polyps are generally a benign finding and unlikely to result in malignant transformation, although in the context of certain conditions (i.e., Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, Juvenile polyps, and Cowden syndrome), they have an increased risk of malignant transformation.

B) CORRECT:

Adenomatous polyps (i.e., tubular adenoma, tubulovillous adenoma, or villous adenoma) carry the highest risk of malignant transformation of all types of colonic polyps. A villous adenomatous polyp has the highest risk (∼ 50%) of malignant transformation of the three types of adenomatous polyps.
Image Description:

Types of colonic polyps are depicted from left to right in descending order of their incidence.

C) INCORRECT:

Tubular adenoma is the most common histological variety of colonic adenoma, comprising ∼ 80% of all adenomatous polyps. These common polyps carry a relatively small risk of malignant transformation (∼ 5%). Increasing size is associated with a higher risk of malignancy. However, another type of polyp is a greater predisposing factor for this patient's condition.

D) INCORRECT:

A leiomyomatous polyp is most often a benign lesion of the muscularis propria or muscularis mucosa (smooth muscle of the gastrointestinal tract) with a very low potential for malignancy. Although they can present with pain, constipation, weight loss, and blood in stool, bleeding, as seen in this patient, it is unlikely to have been a predisposing factor as this type of polyp chiefly affects young women and girls.

E) INCORRECT:

A pedunculated inflammatory polyp, which is seen only in advanced IBD, does not carry any risk of neoplastic transformation. The tissue surrounding a pedunculated inflammatory polyp, as opposed to the inflammatory polyp itself, is prone to dysplasia and therefore at higher risk of neoplastic transformation.
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptomatic iron deficiency anemia and is found to have an irregular, ulcerative growth in the right colon. These findings are highly suggestive of colorectal cancer.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy with no notable medical history reports intermittent cramping abdominal pain. A few weeks earlier, he noticed blood in his stool, which has resolved. He has had no diarrhea, constipation, nausea, anorexia, or weight loss. His blood pressure and other vital signs are normal, as is his abdominal examination. Physical examination shows the findings in the photograph. He also has scattered dark-brown macules on the fingers and gingiva. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

E) INCORRECT:

Cowden syndrome, an autosomal dominant disorder due to heterozygous pathogenic variants in the PTEN gene, is a subtype of PTEN hamartoma tumor syndrome.
