Patients with FAP may also develop adenomatous polyps in the upper gastrointestinal tract, most commonly the duodenum. The lifetime risk for duodenal cancer in patients with FAP is 4% to 12%.

Patients with suspected FAP should ideally begin colon cancer surveillance once they reach 10 to 12 years of age. Colectomy is eventually necessary in all patients with FAP, although the timing depends on the progression of the disease.

Key learning point: Without screening or treatment, patients with familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome have a very high risk of developing colon cancer.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old male presents for a routine examination. His father died from colon cancer at age 40, and genetic testing has confirmed an APC gene mutation in the patient. He has no gastrointestinal complaints. Physical examination is normal. He has never had endoscopic evaluation.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to detect and manage potential colonic polyps in this patient?

choices.text: Wait until age 45 for a baseline colonoscopy
Obtain colonoscopy only if symptoms develop
Perform flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years starting at age 25
Begin annual colonoscopy at this time

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

APC mutation carriers have a significantly elevated risk of adenomatous polyps and colon cancer, often manifesting in adolescence. Guidelines recommend starting endoscopic surveillance in early teens. Waiting until age 45 aligns with average-risk screening, not suitable for those with genetic predispositions like APC mutations.

B) INCORRECT:

In APC mutation carriers, colonic polyps develop early and asymptomatically. Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) involves multiple adenomatous polyps forming in adolescence or early adulthood, progressing to malignancy without symptoms. Delaying colonoscopy until symptoms appear would hinder early detection and management.

C) INCORRECT:

An APC mutation indicates a high risk for early colonic polyps, necessitating screening in early adolescence. Flexible sigmoidoscopy only examines the distal colon and rectum, missing proximal neoplasms. The 5-year interval is insufficient given the rapid polyp growth and malignant transformation potential in APC mutation carriers.

D) CORRECT:

Individuals with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) due to an APC gene mutation are at high risk for developing numerous colonic adenomas, which can progress to colorectal cancer if not monitored. Surveillance guidelines recommend starting colonoscopy between ages 10 and 15 to assess polyp burden and stage the disease. Annual colonoscopy is crucial for early detection of polyps, evaluation of their number and size, and identification of dysplastic changes, guiding timely prophylactic interventions such as colectomy. This proactive approach reduces long-term cancer risk in FAP patients.

Key learning point: In individuals with a family history of familial polyposis syndrome, early colonoscopy screening is crucial for the detection and management of polyps to prevent progression to colorectal cancer.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-day history of blood-speckled stools and a protruding rectal mass. He does not report abdominal pain, changes in bowel habits, or fever. His mother has inflammatory bowel disease. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there are multiple small hyperpigmented macules on his lips, buccal mucosa, palms, and soles. His abdomen is soft with no organomegaly. Rectal examination reveals a 4-cm pedunculated polyp with superficial excoriations on the mucosa. Colonoscopy identifies 14 polyps. Biopsy shows hamartomatous mucosal polyps. This diagnosis is most likely associated with which one of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Individuals with PJS are at increased risk of developing ovarian, breast, and pancreatic cancers. In addition, individuals with PJS have a 40% lifetime risk of developing colorectal cancer.

Key learning point: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is characterized by mucocutaneous pigmentation and hamartomatous polyps, and is associated with an increased risk of pancreatic, colorectal, breast, and ovarian cancers.
Image Description:

Dark-brown, hyperpigmented macules are visible on the lips (perioral lentigines).

This is a characteristic cutaneous manifestation of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. Similar spots are typically found on the buccal mucosa, palms, and soles.

B) INCORRECT:

Mandibular osteomas are not associated with PJS but with Gardner syndrome, a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). The underlying gene mutation predisposes to bony and soft tissue tumors (e.g., osteomas, desmoid tumors, epidermoid cysts) in addition to the colonic findings of FAP. This individual has hamartomatous rather than neoplastic polyps, which rules out FAP.

C) INCORRECT:

Enterovesicular fistula formation is not associated with PJS but is a common complication of Crohn disease (CD), which is an uncommon cause of bloody stools. In addition, this patient's family history is a risk factor for CD. However, the polyps found on colonoscopy and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation are not consistent with CD.

D) INCORRECT:

Thyroid adenomas are not associated with PJS but are seen in Cowden syndrome, an autosomal dominant condition that also manifests with GI polyps and skin manifestations. The typical skin manifestations in this syndrome are papules and hyperkeratosis rather than the hyperpigmentation seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Brain tumors, such as medulloblastoma, are not associated with PJS but with Turcot syndrome, a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis. It is important to rule out this condition in anyone presenting with colonic polyps. However, this patient does not present with headaches, behavioral changes, seizures, sensory deficits, or any other features that would indicate an intracranial process. Additionally, he has hamartomatous rather than neoplastic polyps, which rules out FAP.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a protruding rectal polyp and multiple hamartomatous polyps. In combination with mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 4-day history of bloody stools. He has not experienced nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, or pain with defecation. He reports recurrent episodes of nonbloody diarrhea over the past 6 months. His father died of colon cancer at age 39. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there are small, painless bony swellings on the mandible, forehead, and right shin. Multiple nontender subcutaneous nodules with central black pores are present on the trunk and face. Funduscopic examination reveals multiple, oval, darkly pigmented lesions on the retina. Colonoscopy shows approximately 150 colonic polyps. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) can present with hematochezia, altered bowel habits, and a family history of colonic cancer at a young age, as is the case here. However, this patient does not have the common extraintestinal manifestations of PJS (e.g., hyperpigmented spots on the buccal mucosa, lips, palms, and soles). In addition, polyps in PJS are usually few (< 20) and located mainly in the jejunum, unlike the multiple colonic polyps seen here. Lastly, the osteomas, epidermal cysts, and congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium suggest another condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Family history of colon cancer occurring at a young age is one of the main criteria for hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC). Patients with HNPCC may present with hematochezia and altered bowel habits, as seen here, but colonic polyps are typically absent. Patients with HNPCC are at an increased risk of developing cancers of the stomach, pancreas, small intestine, breast, ovaries, and endometrium. However, the multiple benign tumors that this patient presents with (osteomas, epidermal cysts) and congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium are not seen in HNPCC, making another diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient has features that are also common in juvenile polyposis syndrome (JPS), including hematochezia, altered bowel habits, numerous polyps on colonoscopy, and a family history of colorectal cancer. However, JPS typically becomes symptomatic before the age of 20 years, and the presence of multiple osteomas, epidermal cysts, and congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium is more suggestive of another condition.

D) CORRECT:

Gardner syndrome is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis that manifests with multiple colonic polyps and may cause hematochezia together with extracolonic bone and/or soft tissue lesions, such as osteomas, epidermal cysts, and congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium, all of which are seen here. A family history of colon cancer at a young age furthermore supports this diagnosis. Untreated, Gardner syndrome invariably progresses to colon cancer.

Key learning point: Gardner syndrome is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis characterized by numerous colonic polyps and extracolonic findings such as osteomas, epidermal cysts, and congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium.
Image Description:

Montage of fundus photographs of a right eye of a 20-year-old woman with a family history of FAP

The presence of ≥ 4 round and oval hyperpigmented retinal lesions (black arrows), some with a depigmented halo, suggest atypical congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE), which is associated with FAP.

In this patient, a follow-up colonoscopy found adenomatous polyps, indicating Gardner syndrome, a subtype of FAP.

E) INCORRECT:

Turcot syndrome is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis. The family history of colon cancer at a young age and the presence of numerous colonic polyps in this patient are typical of FAP. However, this patient has no clinical features of brain tumors (e.g., headaches, focal neurological deficits), which are a defining feature of Turcot syndrome. Although imaging would be necessary to definitively rule out a small asymptomatic brain tumor, the presence of multiple osteomas, epidermal cysts, and congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium in this patient makes another diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: This condition manifests with dental abnormalities (e.g., supernumerary and/or impacted teeth) in ∼ 30% of patients.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy with no significant medical history comes to your clinic reporting intermittent cramping abdominal pain. He noticed blood in his stool a few weeks ago, but this has resolved. He denies diarrhea, constipation, nausea, anorexia, or weight loss. Vital signs are normal, and abdominal examination is normal. On physical examination, you observe the findings shown in the photograph. He also has scattered dark-brown macules on his fingers and gingiva. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Addison disease is characterized by a more generalized hyperpigmentation (as opposed to focal hyperpigmentation on the oral mucosa and palms) with nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, weakness, and weight loss. Unlike patients with polyposis, patients with Addison disease would not be expected to experience intermittent bloody stools.

B) INCORRECT:

In dysplastic nevus syndrome, multiple dysplastic nevi may be present anywhere on the skin but do not preferentially involve the oral mucosa or fingers.

C) INCORRECT:

Cowden syndrome, an autosomal dominant disorder due to heterozygous pathogenic variants in the PTEN gene, is a subtype of PTEN hamartoma tumor syndrome. It is associated with increased risk for thyroid, breast, colorectal, kidney, and uterine cancers. Cutaneous findings include flesh-colored facial papules (trichilemmomas) and oral mucosal papillomatosis.

D) CORRECT:

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by melanocytic macules of the lips, buccal mucosa, and digits and by multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps. Anemia, rectal bleeding, and abdominal pain due to obstruction and intussusception are common presenting symptoms in about half of affected patients by 20 years of age. The syndrome, caused by heterozygous pathogenic variants in the STK11 tumor-suppressor gene, is associated with increased risk for gastrointestinal, pancreatic, breast, ovarian, lung, and uterine cancers.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in an adolescent with abdominal pain, intermittent bloody stools, and hyperpigmented macules on the oral mucosa and fingers is Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Gardner syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder that is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis. Its skin manifestations include epidermoid cysts and fibromas. The risk for malignant transformation of colonic polyps in Gardner syndrome approaches 100%.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to your clinic after noticing dark red blood in her stools for the past month. The bleeding was initially intermittent but is now present with every bowel movement, mixed with stool and on the toilet paper. Her maternal grandfather and great-grandmother both died of colon cancer at a young age, and her maternal aunt is currently receiving treatment for medulloblastoma. Colonoscopy reveals 20 to 30 adenomatous polyps scattered throughout her transverse and descending colon and rectum. Which one of the following is this patient most likely to develop?

choices.text: Glioma of the central nervous system.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ulcerative colitis is associated with an increased risk for colon cancer, but patients with FAP are not at increased risk for ulcerative colitis.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has gastrointestinal bleeding, a strong family history of colon cancer, and more than 10 adenomatous polyps detected on colonoscopy. The most likely diagnosis is familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), an autosomal dominant disease that is characterized by the presence of hundreds of thousands of colorectal adenomas in one’s lifetime. Polyposis typically develops in the second and third decade of life, but polyps may begin to emerge as early as age 8, with a mean age of 16.

Given the volume and early onset of polyposis in patients with FAP, the lifetime risk for colon cancer is very high — nearly 100% if the patient does not undergo screening and treatment. Although patients with FAP may present with abdominal pain, diarrhea, or gastrointestinal bleeding (as in this case), most remain asymptomatic until they present with colon cancer. The mean age of colon cancer diagnosis in patients with FAP is 45 years.

Patients with FAP may also develop adenomatous polyps in the upper gastrointestinal tract, most commonly the duodenum. The lifetime risk for duodenal cancer in patients with FAP is 4% to 12%.

Patients with suspected FAP should ideally begin colon cancer surveillance once they reach 10 to 12 years of age. Colectomy is eventually necessary in all patients with FAP, although the timing depends on the progression of the disease.

Key learning point: Without screening or treatment, patients with familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome have a very high risk of developing colon cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

FAP is associated with malignancies outside the gastrointestinal tract as well, including follicular or papillary thyroid cancer, hepatoblastoma, and medulloblastoma. However, the lifetime risk for these cancers is much lower (<3%) than the lifetime risk for colon cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

The risk for endometrial cancer is increased in patients with hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC; Lynch syndrome) but not FAP. Like FAP, HNPCC is an autosomal dominant condition that predisposes individuals to colon cancer in the second and third decades of life, but as the name implies, affected patients do not have a multitude of adenomatous polyps. Patients with HNPCC have an approximately 70% lifetime risk for colon cancer and a 15% to 65% risk for endometrial cancer, depending on the specific mutation in the patient’s family. HNPCC is also associated with other malignancies of the gastrointestinal tract, including gastric cancer and biliary cancer, and with gliomas of the central nervous system.

E) INCORRECT:

The risk for endometrial cancer is increased in patients with hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC; Lynch syndrome) but not FAP. HNPCC is also associated with other malignancies of the gastrointestinal tract, including gastric cancer and biliary cancer, and with gliomas of the central nervous system.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man presents with intermittent rectal bleeding for the past 3 months and unintentional weight loss of 3 kg. He has no abdominal pain. His father died of colon cancer at age 39. Physical examination reveals multiple small, firm nodules on the scalp. He reports a previous benign jaw tumor removed at age 20. Colonoscopy shows hundreds of adenomatous polyps throughout the colon and rectum. Genetic testing was offered, but results are pending (see reports).

Colonoscopy: Hundreds of adenomatous polyps throughout the colon and rectum
Biopsy of polyp: Tubular adenoma

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), or Lynch syndrome, typically presents with a few adenomatous polyps that rapidly progress to carcinoma, not hundreds of polyps. The extracolonic manifestations, such as scalp nodules and a benign jaw tumor, are more specific to a polyposis syndrome, not Lynch syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Juvenile polyposis syndrome involves hamartomatous polyps, unlike the adenomatous polyps found here. The extracolonic findings, such as scalp nodules and a benign jaw tumor, are not typical of juvenile polyposis syndrome. The family history of early-onset colon cancer further reduces the likelihood of this diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is associated with hamartomatous polyps, not adenomatous polyps. It also presents with mucocutaneous pigmentation, such as dark spots on the lips, which are absent here. The presence of adenomatous polyps and lack of pigmentation make Peutz-Jeghers syndrome unlikely.

D) CORRECT:

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) results from a germline mutation in the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene, leading to the development of hundreds to thousands of adenomatous polyps in the colon and rectum. The early onset and family history of colon cancer indicate an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern typical of FAP. Extracolonic manifestations, such as osteomas and benign jaw tumors, suggest the Gardner variant of FAP. These clinical features connect the molecular defect to the phenotypic changes observed in affected individuals.

Key learning point: Familial Adenomatous Polyposis is characterized by the development of numerous adenomatous polyps in the colon and rectum, with a high risk of progression to colorectal cancer if untreated.
